data.summary: Class A ordinary shares & Class B ordinary shares have identical rights, except related to the dividend access mechanism, which applies only to the Class B ordinary shares.
data.title: What is the difference between A & B shares?
data.maintext:
Dividends paid on Class A ordinary shares have a Dutch source for tax purposes & are subject to Dutch withholding tax (see note 1 - Taxation). It is the expectation & the intention, although there can be no certainty, that holders of Class B ordinary shares will receive dividends via the dividend access mechanism (see note 2 - Dividend Access Mechanism).

Any dividends paid on the dividend access share will have a UK source for Dutch & UK tax purposes; there will be no UK or Dutch withholding tax on such dividends & certain holders (not including US holders) of Class B ordinary shares or Class B ADSs will be entitled to a UK tax credit in respect of their proportional share of such dividends.

Note 1 - Taxation

Royal Dutch Shell is incorporated in Engl& & Wales & tax-resident in the Netherlands. As a tax resident of the Netherlands, it is generally required by Dutch law to withhold tax at a rate of 15% on dividends with effect from January 1, 2007 (in 2006 the withholding tax rate was 25%) on its ordinary shares & ADSs, subject to the provisions of any applicable tax convention or domestic law.

metadata.view: What is the difference between A & B shares?

data.title: What is an ADS or an ADR?
data.maintext:
ADS stands for an American Depositary Share. ADSs are listed on the NYSE under the symbols RDS.A & RDS.B. Each ADS represents two ordinary shares, two A Shares in the case of RDS.A or two B Shares in the case of RDS.B. ADS ownership is evidenced by American Depositary Receipts or ADRs. ADSs are quoted & traded in U.S. dollars in the U.S. securities market. Also, the dividends are paid to investor in U.S. dollars.

ADSs were specifically designed to facilitate the purchase, holding & sale of non-U.S. securities by U.S. investors, & to provide a corporate finance vehicle for non-U.S. companies. ADSs can be held in book-entry form or as a physical certificate.

An ADR is a negotiable U.S. certificate representing ownership of the ADSs in a non-U.S. corporation. In many cases the terms ADR & ADS are used interchangeably.

metadata.view: What is an ADS or an ADR?
